Glossary

  • Accuracy - A GDPR principle requiring that personal data must be correct, up to date, and free from errors.

  • Accountability - The obligation of organisations to demonstrate compliance with GDPR principles and ensure effective safeguards are in place.

  • Age of Digital Consent - The minimum age at which a person can legally consent to the processing of their personal data. Under GDPR, it is set at 16 by default but may be lowered to 13 by Member States.

  • Consent - Freely given, specific, informed, and unambiguous agreement by an individual to allow their personal data to be processed.

  • Contractual Necessity - A lawful basis for processing data when it is required to fulfil a contract, such as using employee data to process salary payments.

  • Controller - The person or organisation that determines why and how personal data is processed.

  • Cookies - Small files stored on a user’s device by websites to remember preferences or track behaviour online.

  • Cross-Border Cases - Situations where personal data breaches or processing involve more than one EU country, requiring cooperation between national DPAs.

  • Data Minimisation - A GDPR principle requiring organisations to collect only the data that is strictly necessary for a specific purpose.

  • Data Protection Authority (DPA) - An independent regulator in each EU country responsible for enforcing GDPR, investigating complaints, issuing fines, and providing guidance.

  • Integrity and Confidentiality - A GDPR principle requiring that personal data is safeguarded against unauthorised access, misuse, or disclosure.

  • Lawful Basis - A legal justification required under GDPR for processing personal data, such as consent, contractual necessity, legal obligation, legitimate interest, or protection of vital interests.

  • Legitimate Interest - A lawful basis where an organisation processes data for a purpose that benefits it or others, provided it does not override the rights of individuals.

  • One-Stop Shop Mechanism - A GDPR framework ensuring that in cross-border cases, one lead supervisory authority (usually where the organisation’s main establishment is located) coordinates enforcement across the EU.

  • Processor - A person or organisation that processes personal data on behalf of a controller, following their instructions.

  • Pseudonymisation - A data protection method where personal identifiers are replaced with codes, making it harder to trace data back to an individual without additional information.

  • Right to Compensation - The right of individuals to claim damages in court if their data protection rights are violated and they suffer harm.

  • Right to Object - The right of individuals to refuse the processing of their data in certain circumstances, particularly for direct marketing.

  • Storage Limitation - A GDPR principle requiring that personal data must not be kept longer than necessary for the purpose it was collected.

  • Tokenisation - A security method, often used in financial transactions, where sensitive data such as credit card numbers is replaced with random tokens to prevent misuse.
